block.p: Charles M. Young dances around the racial issues involved in Michael Bolton's cover versions of soul music [ "Platinum Pop in the Key of E," Oct. 4 ] . Critics decry the popularity of Mr. Bolton's, as well as the Commitments', appropriation of these songs, yet today's rhythm-and-blues singers and urban radio for black audiences ignore soul music. When Bobby Brown was asked to induct Wilson Pickett into the Rock-and-Roll Hall of Fame last year, he had to ask who Pickett was.

Charles M. Young dances around the racial issues involved in Michael Bolton's cover versions of soul music [ "Platinum Pop in the Key of E," Oct. 4 ] . Critics decry the popularity of Mr. Bolton's, as well as the Commitments', appropriation of these songs, yet today's rhythm-and-blues singers and urban radio for black audiences ignore soul music. When Bobby Brown was asked to induct Wilson Pickett into the Rock-and-Roll Hall of Fame last year, he had to ask who Pickett was.

Just as white British rockers in the 1960's rekindled interest here in long-ignored black blues musicians, Mr. Bolton can rekindle an interest in a neglected format of the African-American musical heritage among whites and blacks. NORA L. MANDEL Forest Hills, N. Y.
